--- title: "Penguins Dataset" author: "Musie Beyene PhD." date: "2025-2-11" categories: [news, code, analysis] image: "gemini_generated_image.jpeg" --- # Penguins Dataset Let us import some libraries and load the penguins dataset. ::: {#6f5732d1 .cell execution_count=1} ``` {.python .cell-code} import pandas as pd import matplotlib.pyplot as plt import seaborn as sns df_penguins = sns.load_dataset("penguins") df_penguins.head() ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display execution_count=11} ```{=html}
species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g sex
0 Adelie Torgersen 39.1 18.7 181.0 3750.0 Male
1 Adelie Torgersen 39.5 17.4 186.0 3800.0 Female
2 Adelie Torgersen 40.3 18.0 195.0 3250.0 Female
3 Adelie Torgersen NaN NaN NaN NaN NaN
4 Adelie Torgersen 36.7 19.3 193.0 3450.0 Female
``` ::: ::: Let us look at the distribution of the body mass of the penguins by species. ::: {#61c1893d .cell execution_count=2} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.title("Distribution of Body Mass of Penguins") sns.kdeplot(x="body_mass_g", hue="species", data=df_penguins, fill=True); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-3-output-1.png){width=629 height=449} ::: ::: Notice the distribution of the Gentoo penguins. It looks bimodal. One possible reason is a difference between male and females of that species. Let us look at the distribution of the body mass of that species by species and sex. ::: {#48ffbd5a .cell execution_count=3} ``` {.python .cell-code} plt.title("Distribution of Body Mass of Gentoo Penguins") sns.kdeplot(x="body_mass_g", hue="sex", data=df_penguins[df_penguins["species"] == "Gentoo"], fill=True); ``` ::: {.cell-output .cell-output-display} ![](index_files/figure-html/cell-4-output-1.png){width=614 height=449} ::: ::: Indeed, the separation is by sex.
